newsitem.title: USA: UAW targets Ford in U.S. auto labor talks.
newsitem.headline: UAW targets Ford in U.S. auto labor talks.

text.p: The United Auto Workers has targeted Ford Motor Co. to lead labor contract negotiations between union and the Big Three U.S. automakers, a source close to the talks said.
The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the union informed Ford's top management of the decision earlier on Tuesday.
The selection will allow the No. 2 U.S. automaker to negotiate an agreement that will serve as a pattern for rivals General Motors Corp and Chrysler Corp to follow.
Contracts covering about 400,000 U.S. hourly workers at all three companies expire September 14. As the target company, Ford faces the threat of a national strike if it fails to strike an agreement.
UAW Vice President Ernest Lofton, who is leading the union's Ford negotiations, later confirmed the choice but downplayed the possibility of a strike.
"They are the lead company in regards to resolving our 1996 negotiations," Lofton said in an interview on WDIV-TV.
Ford spokesman Jon Harmon would only read the following statement: "We're hard at work negotiating with the UAW at the subcommittee level as well as at the main table...
"Our team is working under the assumption that we will be closely involved in whatever transpires over the next two weeks. And that's been our preference all along."
The decision marks the second time in a row that the union has chosen Ford to lead its Big Three U.S. negotiations. Ford negotiated the current pact in 1993.
The UAW's top priorities in the 1996 negotiations are improved job security for its workers and restrictions on the automakers' ability to shift work to lower-cost outside suppliers.
Chrysler has been chosen as the Canadian Auto Workers union's negotiating target. The CAW's Big Three labor contract, covering about 53,000 workers, has been extended until September 17.
